member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Buffer.FastProperties
member.summary: Provides and encapsulates the fast properties that is used in solving and analyzing a sudoku puzzle.

remarks.para: The whole class is a one, which means you can't use clause to create a new instance of this type. In contrast, the class is used for providing with properties used in a cyclic manual searching (i.e. in ).
Some step searchers rely on this class. If you want to call them alone, you should ensure the method in this class is called before using these properties.

If a step searcher doesn't rely on this class, it'll be marked an attribute named . If you find that the step searcher marks that attribute, you can call it everywhere safely; however, if the searcher isn't marked that attribute, you can't call it everywhere unless you call the method .

Please note, all names of properties in this class can also be found in , which means you can also call the property by . Of course, some of them doesn't contain the same one in , but you can find a same property whose execution logic (handling logic) is totally same. For example, is same as . The difference between them is that you shouldn't use until you have called , while can be used everywhere, because it isn't an instant property (which means the calculation begins when you called them, i.e. lazy ones; in contrast, some properties only store values directly, so their values can be got instantly, i.e. instant ones).

member.summary: Defines an instance that stores the options that bound with a instance.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.IManualSolverOptions.IsHodokuMode
member.summary: Indicates whether the solver uses Hodoku mode to solve a sudoku.

remarks.para: Hodoku mode is a mode that imitates a sudoku-solving program called Hodoku to solve a puzzle. In this case, all enabled step searchers will be in ascending order via their's own priority, i.e. the value of the property . On the other hand, this option provides a basic and normal processing behavior of a instance.

However, in this case the difficulty order (ascending or descending order) of steps won't be guaranteed. For example, the possible difficulty rating of a step searched via a UR searcher is between 4.5 and 4.8, and another rating of a step via a chain searcher is between 4.6 and 5.1. If the UR searcher has a larger priority than chain searcher, the solver may find all UR steps firsly in this case, and secondly searches for chains. In some cases, some UR steps found has a larger difficulty rating value than some chain steps found, so the difficulty ratings are unstrictly-handled (i.e. steps are out of ordered).
If you want to strictly handle the difficulty rating, we recommend you set this property value as , but the solver will be processed slower than the case setting the value.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.IManualSolverOptions.IsFastSearching
member.summary: Indicates whether the solver will use fast searching mode to solve puzzles. If the value is , the solver will apply all steps after gathered. In the normal case, solver only fetches the first found step to apply.

member.summary: Provides the solver result after solves a puzzle.

summary.para: Indicates the wrong step found. In general cases, if the property keeps value, it'll mean the puzzle is invalid to solve, or the solver has found one error step to apply, that causes the original puzzle become invalid. In this case we can check this property to get the wrong information to debug the error, or tell the author himself directly, with the inner value of this property held.
However, if the puzzle is successful to be solved, the property won't contain any value, so it'll keep the reference. Therefore, please check the nullability of this property before using.

In general, this table will tell us the nullability of this property:
Nullability Description
Not The puzzle is failed to solve, and the solver has found an invalid step to apply.
Other cases.

summary.para: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 20.0M.
Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first solving step. If the puzzle has not solved or the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .

When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first step before the first one whose conclusion is . If the puzzle has not solved or solved by other solvers, this value will be 20.0M.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Searchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an Almost Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Almost Locked Pair
Almost Locked Triple
Almost Locked Quadruple

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Searchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.GetAll(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Step},Sudoku.Data.Grid@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Sudoku.Data.Cells@,Sudoku.Data.Cells@,Sudoku.Data.Cells@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Process the calculation.
member.param: Indicates whether the searcher only searching for one step is okay.

remarks.para:
The diagrams:
ALP: abx aby | ab abz |
ALT: abcw abcx | abc abc abcy abcz |
Algorithm:

If the cell ab (in ALP) or abc (in ALT) is filled with the digit p, then the cells abx and aby (in ALP) and abcw and abcx (in ALT) can't fill the digit p. Therefore the digit p can only be filled into the left-side block.
If the block only contains those cells that can contain the digit p, the ALP or ALT will be formed, and the elimination is z (in ALP) and y and z (in ALT).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Searchers.ISingleStepSearcher.ShowDirectLines
member.summary: Indicates whether the solver shows the direct lines (cross-hatching information).

remarks.para:
Direct lines is a concept that describes the crosshatching information of a hidden single. For example, in this following grid:
.---------.---------.---------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . 1 | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :---------+---------+---------: | . . 1 | x x x | . . . | | . . . | x . x | . . . | | . . . | x x x | 1 . . | :---------+---------+---------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | 1 . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '---------'---------'---------'
The start point of the direct lines are:
r4c3(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r4c456.
r2c6(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r456c6.
r6c7(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r6c456.
r8c4(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r456c4.
All the end points may be displayed using a cross mark ('x'), and the start point may be used a circle mark ('o').

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Searchers.LockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Pointing
Claiming

remarks.para: The main idea of this searching operation:

.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
For example, if the cells C form a locked candidates, there'll be two cases:
Pointing (Type 1): Cells A contains the digit, but cells B doesn't.
Claiming (Type 2): Cells B contains the digit, but cells A doesn't.

Therefore, the algorithm is: Use bitwise-or operator | to gather all candidate masks from cells A, cells B and cells C, and suppose the notation a is the mask result for cells A, b is the mask result for cells B, and c is the mask result for cells C. If the equation (c & (a ^ b)) != 0 is correct, the locked candidates exists, and the result of the expression c & (a ^ b) is a mask that holds the digits of the locked candidates.

Why this expression? a ^ b means the digit can only appear in either cells A or cells B. If both or neither, the digit won't contain the locked candidates structure. Because of the optimization of the performance, we use the predefined table to iterate on all possible location where may form a locked candidate.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.SearchingOptions
member.summary: Indicates the options aiming to s while searching.
member.param: Indicates the priority of this technique.
Indicates which areas the step searcher is enabled and works well. The default value is both and .

param.name: DisplayingLevel
param.para: Indicates the displaying level of this technique.
The display level means the which level the technique is at. All higher leveled techniques won't display on the screen when the searchers at the current level have found technique instances.

In order to enhance the performance, this attribute is used on . For example, if Alternating Inference Chain (AIC) is at the level but Forcing Chains (FC) is at the level , when we find any AIC technique instances, FC won't be checked at the same time
This attribute is also used for grouping those the searchers, especially in Sudoku Explainer mode.

param.name: DisabledReason
param.para: Indicates whether the current searcher has bug to fix, or something else to describe why the searcher is (or should be) disabled.
The property must contain a value that differs with when the property isn't .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Step.IsChaining
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a chain. The chain techiques are:
Wings
Regular wings (XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing, etc.)
Irregular wings (W-Wing, M-Wing, Split-Wing, Local-Wing, Hybrid-Wing)
Short chains
Two strong links (Skyscraper, Two-string kite, Turbot fish)
ALS chaining-like techniques (ALS-XZ, ALS-XY-Wing, ALS-W-Wing)
Empty rectangle
Long chains
Forcing chains
Dynamic forcing chains

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Step.IsDeadlyPattern
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a deadly pattern. The deadly pattern techniques are:
Bi-value patterns
Unique rectangle (i.e. Uniqueness test)
Unique loop
Bi-value universal grave
Multi-value patterns
Extended rectangle
Unique square
Borescoper's deadly pattern
Qiu's deadly pattern
Other deadly patterns
Reverse bi-value universal grave

Limited by the C# language, here we creates a new property to pass the value and assign it to the property . param.name: AbsoluteOffset
param.para: Indicates the absolute offset.

The value will be an value to compare all possible cases of unique rectangle structures to be iterated. The greater the value is, the later the unique rectangle structure will be processed. The value must be between 0 and 485. Other values are invalid and useless. The number of all possible unique rectangle structures is 486.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Steps.IStep
member.summary: Provides a basic manual solving step.

summary.para: Indicates whether the difficulty rating of this technique should be shown in the output screen. Some techniques such as Gurth's symmetrical placement doesn't need to show the difficulty (because the difficulty of this technique is unstable).
If the value is , the analysis result won't show the difficulty of this instance.
The default value is .
Indicates whether the step is an EST (i.e. Elementary Sudoku Technique) step.

Here we define that the techniques often appearing and commonly to be used as below are ESTs:
Full House, Last Digit, Hidden Single, Naked Single
Pointing, Claiming
Naked Pair, Naked Triple, Naked Quarduple
Naked Pair (+), Naked Triple (+), Naked Quarduple (+)
Hidden Pair, Hidden Triple, Hidden Quarduple
Locked Pair, Locked Triple
The default value of this property is .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Steps.IStep.Name
member.summary: Indicates the technique name. The default value is in the resource dictionary.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Steps.IStep.Format
member.summary: Gets the format of the current instance.
member.returns: Returns a result. If the resource dictionary doesn't contain any valid formats here, the result value will be .

remarks.para:
A format is the better way to format the result text of this technique information instance, It'll be represented by the normal characters and the placeholders, e.g.
"{Name}: Cells {CellsStr} => {ElimsStr}"
Here the string result shouldn't be with the leading '$' character, because this is a format string, rather than a interpolated string.

Because this property will get the value from the resource dictionary, the property supports multiple language switching, which is better than the normal methods and . Therefore, this property is the substitution plan of those two methods.
